meanings.def: used to refer to actions that you do not mention by name or do not know about
examples: What are you doing this evening?
We will do what we can to help.
Are you doing anything tomorrow evening?
The company ought to do something about the poor service.
What have you done to your hair?
There's nothing to do (= no means of passing the time in an enjoyable way) in this place.
There's nothing we can do about it (= we can't change the situation).
What can I do for you (= how can I help)?

meanings.def: to act or behave in the way mentioned
examples: do as… Do as you're told!
They are free to do as they please.
+ adv./prep. You would do well to (= I advise you to) consider all the options before buying.
Just do what they tell you to do.
Do whatever you like.

meanings.def: used to ask or talk about the success or progress of somebody/something
examples: How is the business doing?
She did well out of (= made a big profit from) the deal.
He's doing very well at school (= his work is good).
Both mother and baby are doing well (= after the birth of the baby).
(informal) How are you doing (= how are you)?

meanings.def: to work at or perform an activity or a task
examples: I'm doing some research on the subject.
I have a number of things to do today.
I do aerobics once a week.
Let's do (= meet for) lunch.
(informal) Sorry. I don't do funny (= I can't be funny).

meanings.def: to perform the activity or task mentioned
examples: do the ironing, cooking, shopping, etc. I like listening to the radio when I'm doing the ironing.
You could help me by doing the dishes.
do some, a little, etc. acting, writing, etc. She did a lot of acting when she was at college.
Let me do the dishes.
Michael said he would do the kitchen floor.
It’s your turn to do the table.
to do the shopping/​cleaning/​ironing/​vacuuming
He makes a great lasagne.
I’ll make breakfast while you’re having a shower.
Can you get dinner while I put the kids to bed?
Sit down—I’ll fix supper for you.

meanings.def: used with nouns to talk about tasks such as cleaning, washing, arranging, etc.
examples: to do (= wash) the dishes
to do (= arrange) the flowers
I like the way you've done your hair.

meanings.def: to work at something as a job
examples: What do you do (= what is your job)?
What does she want to do when she leaves school?
What did she do for a living?
What's Tom doing these days?

meanings.def: to learn or study something
examples: I'm doing physics, biology and chemistry.
Have you done any (= studied anything by) Keats?

meanings.def: to find the answer to something; to solve something
examples: I can't do this sum.
Are you good at doing crosswords?

meanings.def: to produce, make or provide something
examples: do something to do a drawing/painting/sketch
Does this pub do lunches?
Who's doing the food for the wedding reception?
Many hotels don't do single rooms at all.
do something for somebody I'll do a copy for you.
do somebody something I'll do you a copy.
She makes her own clothes.
She made a good impression on the interviewer.
He did a beautiful drawing of a house.
Who’s doing the food for the party?
Scientists disagree about how the universe was created.
to develop new software
a factory that produces microchips
to generate electricity
Brainstorming is a good way of generating ideas.
Rearrange the letters to form a new word.
The chain is formed from 136 links.
He did a beautiful drawing of a house.
Who's doing the flowers for the wedding?

meanings.def: to be suitable or be enough for somebody/something
examples: ‘Can you lend me some money?’ ‘Sure—will $20 do?’
do for somebody/something These shoes won't do for the party.
do as something The box will do fine as a table.
do somebody (+ adv./prep.) (especially British English) This room will do me nicely, thank you (= it has everything I need).

meanings.def: to perform or produce a play, an opera, etc.
examples: The local dramatic society is doing ‘Hamlet’ next month.

meanings.def: to copy somebody’s behaviour or the way somebody speaks, sings, etc., especially in order to make people laugh
examples: He does a great Elvis Presley.
Can you do a Welsh accent?

meanings.def: to finish something
examples: Sit there and wait till I'm done.
be done doing something I've done talking—let's get started.
get something done Did you get your article done in time?

meanings.def: to travel a particular distance
examples: How many miles did you do during your tour?
My car does 40 miles to the gallon (= uses one gallon of petrol to travel 40 miles).

meanings.def: to complete a journey
examples: We did the round trip in two hours.

meanings.def: to travel at or reach a particular speed
examples: The car was doing 90 miles an hour.

meanings.def: to visit a place as a tourist
examples: We did Tokyo in three days.

meanings.def: to spend a period of time doing something
examples: She did a year at college, but then dropped out.
He did six years (= in prison) for armed robbery.

meanings.def: to deal with or attend to somebody/something
examples: The hairdresser said she could do me (= cut my hair) at three.

meanings.def: to cook something
examples: How would you like your steak done?

meanings.def: to cheat somebody
examples: be done This isn't a genuine antique—you've been done.

meanings.def: to punish somebody
examples: They did him for tax evasion.
She got done for speeding.

meanings.def: to steal from a place
examples: The gang did a warehouse and a supermarket.

meanings.def: to take an illegal drug
examples: He doesn't smoke, drink or do drugs.

meanings.def: to have sex with somebody
to be something that somebody does not need to know about or should not get involved in
examples: It's my decision—it's nothing to do with you.
‘How much do you earn?’ ‘What's it got to do with you?’
We don't have very much to do with our neighbours (= we do not speak to them very often).
I'd have nothing to do with him, if I were you.

meanings.def: to be about or connected with somebody/something
examples: ‘What do you want to see me about?’ ‘It's to do with that letter you sent me.’
Her job has something to do with computers.
Hard work has a lot to do with (= is an important reason for) her success.

meanings.def: to treat somebody in a way that is right, good, etc.
examples: If we cannot keep the streets safe, then we are not doing right by the people of this country.
We need to do better by those suffering from mental illness.
We have done badly by the unemployed.

meanings.def: used to say that a situation is not acceptable and should be changed or improved
examples: This is the third time you've been late this week; it simply won't do.

meanings.def: used to say that something does not make somebody look attractive
examples: That hairstyle doesn't do anything for her.

meanings.def: used to refuse a request
examples: ‘Can you lend me ten dollars?’ ‘Nothing doing!’

meanings.def: used to show that you intend to stop somebody from doing something that they were going to do
examples: Sharon went to get into the taxi. ‘Oh no you don't,’ said Steve.

meanings.def: used to show that you will not accept something any longer
examples: That does it, I'm off. I'm not having you swear at me like that.

meanings.def: used to say that an accident, a mistake, etc. has had a very bad effect on something
examples: That's done it. You've completely broken it this time.

meanings.def: used to order somebody to stop doing or saying something
examples: That'll do, children—you're getting far too noisy.

meanings.def: used to ask how somebody manages to obtain the thing mentioned
examples: What do you do for entertainment out here?

meanings.def: used to ask why somebody/something is in the place mentioned
examples: What are these shoes doing on my desk?

idioms.idiom: be/have (got) nothing/not much to do with somebody/something
idioms.def: to be something that somebody does not need to know about or should not get involved in
examples: It's my decision—it's nothing to do with you.
‘How much do you earn?’ ‘What's it got to do with you?’
We don't have very much to do with our neighbours (= we do not speak to them very often).
I'd have nothing to do with him, if I were you.

idioms.idiom: be/have to do with somebody/something | have (got) something, a lot, etc. to do with somebody/something
idioms.def: to be about or connected with somebody/something
examples: ‘What do you want to see me about?’ ‘It's to do with that letter you sent me.’
Her job has something to do with computers.
Hard work has a lot to do with (= is an important reason for) her success.

idioms.idiom: do right, well, etc. by somebody
idioms.def: to treat somebody in a way that is right, good, etc.
examples: If we cannot keep the streets safe, then we are not doing right by the people of this country.
We need to do better by those suffering from mental illness.
We have done badly by the unemployed.

idioms.def: used to say that a situation is not acceptable and should be changed or improved
examples: This is the third time you've been late this week; it simply won't do.

idioms.idiom: not do anything/a lot/much for somebody
idioms.def: used to say that something does not make somebody look attractive
examples: That hairstyle doesn't do anything for her.
‘Can you lend me ten dollars?’ ‘Nothing doing!’

idioms.def: used to show that you intend to stop somebody from doing something that they were going to do
examples: Sharon went to get into the taxi. ‘Oh no you don't,’ said Steve.

idioms.def: used to show that you will not accept something any longer
examples: That does it, I'm off. I'm not having you swear at me like that.

idioms.def: used to say that an accident, a mistake, etc. has had a very bad effect on something
examples: That's done it. You've completely broken it this time.

idioms.def: used to order somebody to stop doing or saying something
examples: That'll do, children—you're getting far too noisy.

idioms.idiom: what do you do for something?
idioms.def: used to ask how somebody manages to obtain the thing mentioned
examples: What do you do for entertainment out here?

idioms.def: used to ask why somebody/something is in the place mentioned
examples: What are these shoes doing on my desk?

meanings.def: used before a full verb to form negative sentences and questions
examples: I don't like fish.
They didn't go to Paris.
Don't forget to write.
Does she speak French?

meanings.def: used to make question tags (= short questions at the end of statements)
examples: You live in New York, don't you?
She doesn't work here, does she?

meanings.def: used to avoid repeating a full verb
examples: He plays better than he did a year ago.
She works harder than he does.
He put more feeling into the words than he had ever done before.
‘Who won?’ ‘I did.’
‘I love peaches.’ ‘So do I.’
‘I don't want to go back.’ ‘Neither do I.’

meanings.def: used when no other auxiliary verb is present, to emphasize what you are saying
examples: He does look tired.
She did at least write to say thank you.
(British English) Do shut up!

meanings.def: used to change the order of the subject and verb when an adverb is moved to the front
examples: Not only does she speak Spanish, she's also good with computers.

meanings.def: a party; a social event
examples: Are you having a big do for your birthday?
I suppose we should have a bit of a do to celebrate.
They’re having some special do in London.

meanings.def: the style in which a person's hair is arranged
examples: I like your new do, Alex.

meanings.def: rules that you should follow
examples: Here are some dos and don'ts for exercise during pregnancy.

meanings.def: used to ask for fair treatment or to claim that a situation is fair
examples: Fair dos—we were here first.
Fair do's—you can't expect them to cancel everything just because you can't make it.
Come on, fair dos—you’ve had your chance, now let me try.
Here are some dos and don'ts for exercise during pregnancy.

idioms.def: used to ask for fair treatment or to claim that a situation is fair
examples: Fair dos—we were here first.
Fair do's—you can't expect them to cancel everything just because you can't make it.
Come on, fair dos—you’ve had your chance, now let me try.

meanings.def: the 1st and 8th note of a major scale
ditto
